51-percent-attack.definition: When one or a group of miners control greater than 50% of the network's mining hashrate or computational power.

absolute-advantage.definition: An economics concept in which one party has a direct advantage in efficiency in producing/providing a specific good or service over another party.

active-management.definition: An investing strategy employed by fund managers aiming to outperform an index or market in order to generate profits.

actively-validated-services-avs.definition: Actively validated services (AVS) continuously monitor and validate for enhanced security, performance, and compliance in blockchain and cryptocurrencies.

ad-hoc.definition: The phrase 'ad hoc' is a phrase of Latin origin that is used in modern English to mean 'for this purpose' or 'specifically for this.'

address.definition: String of text that designates the location of a particular wallet on the blockchain. Often a hashed version of a public key.

airdrop.definition: Distribution of digital assets to the public, by virtue of holding a certain token or by virtue of being an active wallet address.

algorithm.definition: A sequence of unambiguous instructions used for the purpose of solving a problem.

all-or-none-order.definition: An AON order, once placed, must either be filled in its entirety or not at all. This prevents any partial filling of orders.

all-time-high.definition: The highest price of a cryptocurrency in a quote​ currency, such as a dollar, BTC, ETH, or BNB

allocation.definition: Percentage distribution of tokens. For example a project may allocate 40% of tokens to their team.

alpha.definition: The first look at a product released by a team, consisting of the very first version of a primitive, basic software or product.

altcoin.definition: A cryptocurrency that is alternative to Bitcoin. Altcoin is used to describe cryptocurrencies that are not Bitcoin.

angel-investor.definition: Wealthy investors that seek out opportunities to provide funding for entrepreneurs or start-up companies.

anti-money-laundering.definition: Legal and regulatory procedures to minimize and curb the flow of funds generated from illegal or dubious activities.

application-programming-interface.definition: Collection of functions and procedures that allow users to interact with the data of an application.

application-specific-integrated-circuit.definition: An Integrated Circuit customized for maximum performance in a particular use.

arbitrage.definition: Buying and selling of assets over different markets in order to take advantage of differing prices on the same asset.

arc-20.definition: Learn about Atomicals ARC-20 tokens, a token standard for fungible tokens on the Bitcoin blockchain. Explore how they work and their potential use cases.

artificial-intelligence-ai.definition: Explore the transformative power of Artificial Intelligence (AI) across healthcare, business, education, finance, security, manufacturing, and transportation.

asic-resistant.definition: The property of a cryptocurrency that is “immune” to ASIC mining. Allowing the mining to become more decentralized.

asking-price.definition: The lowest price a seller would be willing to accept when placing their sell order while trading an asset on an exchange.

asset-management.definition: A system or method that helps individuals or companies manage assets. Either on behalf of their clients or their own.

assets-under-management-aum.definition: AUM (assets under management) is the market value of financial assets managed by an entity on behalf of clients, indicating influence and operational scale.

asynchronous.definition: Events in electronic systems that do not happen at the same time or speed, or happen independent of the main program flow.

atomic-swap.definition: A technique of peer-to-peer cryptocurrency trading based on smart contract technology that removes the need for intermediaries.

attack-surface.definition: Points in a software environment where an attacker can attempt to enter or extract data from the system.

auction.definition: A live event where assets or services are negotiated through a bidding process, which is often led by an auctioneer.

automated-market-maker-amm.definition: Automated Market Makers (AMMs) are a subset of decentralized exchange (DEX) protocols. They allow users to trade digital assets without the need for an intermediary.

b-tokens.definition: B-Tokens are the name for a range of fully-collateralized wrapped tokens minted by Binance.

bags.definition: The portfolio of coins and tokens one is holding. Often related to a poorly performing bag of assets that investors insist to hold.

beacon-chain.definition: The Beacon Chain is Ethereum’s proof-of-stake (PoS) layer where consensus is reached.

bear-market.definition: A negative trend in prices of a market. It is widely used not only in the cryptocurrency space but also in the traditional markets

benchmark.definition: A measurement standard which can be used to gauge the performance of a particular asset or investment portfolio

bep-1155.definition: The BEP-1155 token standard enables the combination of fungible and non-fungible tokens (NFT) in a single smart contract in the BNB Chain.

bep-20.definition: BEP-20 is a token standard on BNB Smart Chain that extends ERC-20, the most common Ethereum token standard.

bep-721.definition: BEP-721 is a BNB Smart Chain (BSC) token standard that allows for the creation of non-fungible tokens (NFTs).

bep-95.definition: BEP-95 is a Binance Evolution Proposal that introduces a real-time burning mechanism to BNB Smart Chain. It makes BNB tokenomics more dynamic and decentralized.

beta-coefficient.definition: A tool used to measure the volatility of an asset in comparison to the volatility of a specific portfolio or market index.

beta-release.definition: An early version of a program for users to test and for a team to get feedback. This stage comes after the Alpha stage.

bid-price.definition: In the context of financial markets, it is the value buyers offer for an asset, such as a commodity, security, or cryptocurrency.

bid-ask-spread.definition: The difference in price between the lowest asking price and highest bid price on the order book for an asset.

binance-ecosystem-fund.definition: An initiative by Binance to collaborate with partners who care about the blockchain/cryptocurrency ecosystem.

binancian.definition: A "Binancian" is a term referring to individuals who are actively involved with or contribute to the cryptocurrency exchange Binance.

bitcoin.definition: A cryptocurrency created by the pseudonymous developer(s) Satoshi Nakamoto, initially described as a 'Peer-to-Peer e-cash'.

bitcoin-core.definition: Leading implementation of the software that enables users to interact with the Bitcoin network. Initially released by Satoshi.

bitcoin-dominance.definition: The ratio of Bitcoin's market capitalization versus the sum of the market capitalizations of all cryptocurrencies.

bitcoin-maximalists.definition: Bitcoin Maximalists are individuals who believe that bitcoin is the only valuable cryptocurrency and the future of global finance.

bitcoin-pizza.definition: The first known transaction where Bitcoin was exchanged for a physical good. Laszlo Hanyecz paid 10,000 BTC for two pizzas.

black-swan-event.definition: An event that is often entirely unexpected and deviates from the expected result causing widespread ramifications.

block.definition: A computer file that stores transaction data. These can then be arranged in a linear sequence, which will form a blockchain.

block-explorer.definition: Online Blockchain webpage which allows users to browse information about blocks, transactions, balances and more.

block-header.definition: A section in a block containing metadata and a summary of the block's transactions. This is the information hashed when mining.

block-height.definition: The number of blocks in the chain between itself and the first block on that blockchain (genesis block or block 0).

block-reward.definition: The sum of coins awarded by the blockchain protocol to cryptocurrency miners for each successfully mined and validated block.

blockchain.definition: A decentralized, digitized ledger that records transaction information about a cryptocurrency in a chronological order.

binance-blockchain-charity-foundation.definition: The world's first decentralized charity platform to advocate the concept of 'blockchain for social good'.

bloom-filter.definition: A data structure which is able to be used to inform the user whether a particular item is part of a set of items

blue-chip-token.definition: Blue-chip cryptos are coins that have withstood the test of time. These assets are established and reliably valuable.

bnb.definition: Launched after an initial coin offering that ended on July 3rd, 2017. Used for receiving exchange trading fee discounts and more.

bnsol.definition: BNSOL is a tradable token that represents your staked SOL on Binance. It’s a liquid staking token that offers liquidity and capital efficiency.

bollinger-bands.definition: A technical analysis indicator that measures market volatility. It's made of two sidelong bands and a simple moving average.

bond.definition: Bonds are a type of fixed-income investment that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower, typically a business or government.

bounty.definition: A reward posted by a group or individual to incentivize certain work, behavior (such as referrals), or development.

brc-20-tokens.definition: BRC-20 is an experimental token standard that enables the minting and transferring of fungible tokens via the Ordinals protocol on the Bitcoin blockchain.

break-even-point.definition: The point where the total costs of an operation is equivalent to its current value or revenue.

breakeven-multiple.definition: The multiple of the current price by which an asset needs to appreciate in order to reach its previous all-time high.

breakout.definition: When the price of an asset moves outside of a defined range or pattern, typically by breaking out of a support or resistance area.

bscscan.definition: BscScan is a blockchain explorer for BNB Smart Chain (BSC) users. It was developed by the same team behind the popular Ethereum blockchain explorer, Etherscan.

btc-wallet-address.definition: A BTC wallet address is a unique string of letters and numbers used to send and receive Bitcoin transactions.

buidl.definition: Originally derived from HODL, a term referring to keeping your heads down and focusing on building your product.

bull-market.definition: A positive trend in prices of a market. It is widely used not only in the cryptocurrency space but also in the traditional markets

burner-wallet.definition: Explore burner wallets, temporary cryptocurrency wallets that users can use to safely interact with potentially dangerous blockchain applications.

buy-wall.definition: A single huge buy order or the composition of multiple large buy orders at the same price in the order book of a particular market.

candidate-block.definition: A temporary block created by a mining node (miner) to add to the blockchain to receive the block rewards.

candlestick.definition: A graph representation of price action that displays the open, close, high, and low points within a certain period.

capitulation.definition: A period of strong selling activity, where investors give up their positions and sell their holdings as quickly as possible.

censorship-resistance.definition: The property of a cryptocurrency network that prevents any entity from altering transactions on it.

central-bank.definition: A financial institution that acts as a monetary authority and manages a states currency, interest rates, and money supply.

central-bank-digital-currency-cbdc.definition: A Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) is an officially sanctioned digital tender issued by a sovereign central bank. CBDCs can be either wholesale or retail.

central-processing-unit.definition: The part of a computer responsible for interpreting instructions of computer programs and executing operations.

centralized.definition: When the planning and decision-making mechanisms are concentrated in a particular point within a system.

centralized-exchange.definition: Understand the world of centralized exchanges, traditional crypto marketplaces known for high liquidity, advanced trading tools, and risk considerations.

chatgpt.definition: ChatGPT is a language processing model developed by OpenAI. It represents a significant advancement in the field of natural language processing (NLP)

cipher.definition: A method for encrypting and decrypting messages. Ciphers can be divided into symmetric or asymmetric, according to their key model.

circulating-supply.definition: The best approximate number of cryptocurrency coins or tokens that are publicly available and circulating in the market.

cloud.definition: In computer science, a shared pool of resources, which are made available to multiple users through the Internet.

coin.definition: A cryptocurrency or digital cash that is independent of any other platform, which is used as exchange of value.

cold-storage.definition: Discover the essentials of cold storage: learn what it is and how it protects your cryptocurrency holdings.

collateral.definition: Pledging something of value against a loan to guarantee that the person taking the loan will complete repayment.

colocation.definition: A dedicated space in a data center belonging to stock exchanges which is shared with other entities such as high-frequency traders.

commodity-futures-trading-commission.definition: US-based agency responsible for regulating derivatives, including options, swaps, and futures.

compound-interest.definition: Compound interest refers to the interest accumulated on the principal amount, in addition to the interest from previous periods.

confirmation-time.definition: The interval needed for a blockchain transaction to be approved and added to the ledger.

confluence.definition: When multiple investment methods, technical indicators, or trading signals are combined to form a more reliable strategy.

consensus-algorithm.definition: Consensus algorithms are mechanisms that help different computers in a blockchain network agree on what's true, even if some of them aren't playing fair.

consumer-price-index-(cpi).definition: A Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a measure used to track the effects of inflation over a period of time.

contango-and-backwardation.definition: Contango and backwardation are used to describe the relationship between the futures price of a commodity and its expected future spot price. They're useful metrics for trading and hedging.

copy-trading.definition: Discover the benefits of crypto copy trading. Learn how to copy trades, manage risk, diversify investments, and foster shared learning with Binance Academy.

counterparty-risk.definition: Counterparty risk is the risk that one party involved in a financial transaction may default or fail to fulfill its contractual obligations, causing financial losses to the other party.

credentials.definition: Personal information. Examples include username, password, email address, qualifications and many more.

cross-chain-bridges.definition: Blockchain bridges connect different blockchain networks, enabling the movement of digital assets across networks and facilitating interoperability in the crypto space.

crypto-etfs.definition: Crypto ETFs allow investors to gain exposure to the price movements of cryptocurrencies without owning, or managing, them directly.

crypto-fear-and-greed-index.definition: The Crypto Fear and Greed Index is a tool that uses several indicators to help measure the overall cryptocurrency market sentiment on a 0-100 score range.

crypto-protocol.definition: A crypto protocol is a set of rules and procedures that govern behavior in a decentralized network.

crypto-winter.definition: Crypto Winter: The term crypto winter refers to an extended period of declining or stagnant prices and negative sentiment in the cryptocurrency market.

cryptocurrency.definition: A digital currency that is secured by cryptography to work as a medium of exchange within a peer-to-peer (P2P) economic system.

cryptography.definition: The science of using mathematical theories and computation in order to encrypt and decrypt information.

custody.definition: Refers to the holding of assets on behalf of a client. Can also refer to the ownership of one's funds or assets.

daemon.definition: A process operating in the background waiting for a specific event or condition in order to be activated.

danksharding.definition: Danksharding brings a new approach to sharding and plays a crucial role in optimizing data management and transaction processing within the Ethereum network.

dead-cat-bounce.definition: A brief recovery in the price of a declining asset that is shortly followed by a continuation of the downtrend.

death-cross.definition: Explore the death cross and its role in predicting market downturns. Learn how it works and what indicators it can be used with for better market signals.

decentralized-application.definition: DApps are applications that run on a P2P network of computers rather than a central database. Users can freely connect to DApps using crypto wallets.

decentralized-autonomous-cooperative.definition: An organization that is controlled by shareholders rather than a central authority.

decentralized-autonomous-organization.definition: Definition: A system of hard-coded rules that define which actions a decentralized organization will take.

decentralized-exchange.definition: An exchange which does not require users to deposit funds to start trading and does not hold the funds for the user.

decentralized-indexes.definition: A decentralized index is a type of investment vehicle that tracks the performance of multiple cryptocurrencies or digital assets traded on decentralized exchanges.

decryption.definition: The act of reverting an encryption process so that unreadable data (ciphertext) can be converted into readable data (plaintext).

deep-web.definition: The part of the web that is somehow hidden, i.e., not indexed by Google and other traditional web sarch engines.

delisting.definition: The removal of an asset from an exchange either as a request from the project team or as a decision made by the exchange.

depeg.definition: Learn about causes, effects, and preventive measures to avoid a depeg and ensure stablecoin reliability and trust in the cryptocurrency market.

depression.definition: Understanding economic depression: Explore its causes, impacts, and how it might affect cryptocurrency markets in times of financial instability.

design-flaw-attack.definition: Smart contract, decentralized market, or other software created with intentional flaws to trick users interacting with them

diamond-hands.definition: Diamond hands refers to holding a financial asset and not selling it, regardless of its volatility.

difficulty.definition: In cryptocurrency, difficulty indicates the difficulty required to mine a block. Learn more at Binance Academy.

difficulty-bomb.definition: The term 'difficulty bomb' denotes the increase in mining difficulty in Ethereum, as part of its migration to Proof of Stake.

digital-signature.definition: A cryptographic tool to verify the authenticity and integrity of digital data, ensuring the security of data communication and cryptocurrency transactions.

direct-market-access-dma.definition: Direct Market Access allows investors to place trades directly on exchanges, bypassing brokers for faster execution, more control, and lower fees.

divergence.definition: When the market price of an asset and a technical indicator (e.g. RSI, Volume, MACD) are heading in opposite directions.

diversification.definition: The allocation of funds across different types of assets and jurisdictions in order to reduce the overall risks.

do-your-own-research.definition: A valuable piece of advice. It's always wise to research a coin yourself instead of following what others say.

dollar-cost-averaging.definition: Investing fixed dollar amounts over regular periods of time regardless of the price of the asset.

dot-plot.definition: Discover the power of dot plots for visualizing data. Learn about Cleveland and Wilkinson dot plots, and the Fed's dot plot for interest rates.

double-spending.definition: When a given amount of coins are spent more than once. Usually as a result of a race attack or a 51% attack.

eclipse-attack.definition: When peers on the network are malicious and monopolize the network in order to prevent specific nodes from communicating.

efficient-market-hypothesis-emh.definition: An economic theory stating financial markets reflect all available information on the price of assets at any time.

eigenlayer.definition: Discover EigenLayer: a protocol that introduced Ethereum's restaking collective for decentralized trust, offering security, innovation, and agility.

eip.definition: EIP stands for Ethereum Improvement Proposal. It’s a way for the Ethereum community to suggest upgrades or new ideas for the blockchain.

eip-3074.definition: Learn how EIP-3074 could transform Ethereum with enhanced transaction security and flexibility. Stay updated on its integration in the Ethereum Pectra upgrade.

eip-4844.definition: EIP-4844, also known as proto-danksharding, is a proposed upgrade that focuses on reducing Ethereum’s fees and increasing transaction throughput.

eip-7251.definition: EIP-7251 aims to improve Ethereum’s scalability and efficiency by reducing the number of active validators while maintaining decentralization.

eip-7702.definition: Discover how the EIP-7702 proposal can enhance Ethereum by adding smart contract capabilities to externally owned accounts (EOAs).

elasticity.definition: Unravel elasticity, the measure of how one variable reacts to changes in another variable. Learn how elasticity is used in trading and everyday life.

encryption.definition: Conversion of information or data into a secure code in order to prevent unauthorised access to the information or data.

endogenous-variable.definition: Explore endogenous variables, variables that reflect the internal dynamics of an economic model. Learn some examples of endogenous variables in crypto.

erc-1155.definition: Discover the versatility of ERC-1155 tokens. Ideal for gaming, digital collectibles and managing multiple token types efficiently.

erc-20.definition: A technical standard used to issue and implement tokens on the Ethereum blockchain proposed in November 2015 by Fabian Vogelsteller.

erc-404.definition: ERC-404 is a token standard blending fungibility and non-fungibility. Learn about its unique features, semi-fungible nature, mint-and-burn mechanism, and more.

erc-721.definition: An Ethereum based non-fungible token. This means that each token is unique and as a result, not interchangeable.

etf.definition: Learn what ETFs are and explore their role in the cryptocurrency market: benefits, impacts, and challenges for investors and the financial ecosystem.

ethereum-classic.definition: Ethereum Classic (ETC) emerged from the Ethereum hard fork that happened as a result of the 2016 DAO hack. Unlike ETH, ETC still uses Proof of Work.

ethereum-foundation.definition: Explore the Ethereum Foundation's role in blockchain evolution. From research to community support, discover how it shapes the future of decentralized technology.

ethereum-virtual-machine-evm.definition: The Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) is a Turing-complete programmable machine that executes smart contracts, which are typically coded in Solidity.

exchange.definition: A marketplace for cryptocurrencies where users can buy and sell coins.

exogenous-variable.definition: Explore exogenous variables, variables that help explain the external influences that can affect economic models. Learn about exogenous variables in crypto.

exponential-moving-average-ema.definition: Exponential moving averages (EMAs) are charting tools that give more weight to the recent price data, providing a more responsive view of the market trend.

externally-owned-account-eoa.definition: Learn about externally owned accounts (EOAs) on Ethereum, how they work, their role in transactions, and the importance of securing your private key.

fakeout.definition: A situation where a trader enters a position betting on a price movement that quickly reverses or ultimately doesn’t happen.

falling-knife.definition: Refers to the action of purchasing an asset while it is rapidly declining in price under the expectation that it will bounce.

fan-tokens.definition: Fan tokens are digital assets that are created by sports teams, clubs or brands to increase fan engagement and create new revenue streams.

fear-of-missing-out.definition: The feeling of fear and anxiety that you might be missing out on a potentially profitable opportunity.

fear-uncertainty-and-doubt.definition: A marketing strategy used to spread fear and insecurity among customers, traders, or investors.

fiat.definition: Money that a government has declared to be legal tender.

fibonacci-retracement.definition: Fibonacci Retracement is a popular technical analysis (TA) tool used by traders to identify potential support and resistance levels in financial markets.

fill-or-kill-order.definition: A buy or sell order which must be executed immediately in its entirety or else it will be cancelled.

finality.definition: The assurance or guarantee that completed (cryptocurrency) transactions cannot be altered, reversed or canceled.

first-mover-advantage.definition: A competitive advantage of the first project to bring a service or product into a new and unexplored market or industry.

fiscal-policy.definition: Describes how authorities adjusts the tax rates of a country, influencing how public funds should be collected and used.

flappening.definition: The name to describe the moment when Litecoin (LTC) surpassed Bitcoin Cash (BCH) in terms of market capitalization

flashbots.definition: Explore Flashbots, a research & development organization focused on refining MEV-related blockchain solutions on Ethereum.

flippening.definition: The name to describe the moment when/if Ethereum (ETH) surpasses Bitcoin (BTC) in terms of market capitalization

flow-variable.definition: Explore flow variables, measurements that reflect the quantity of something over a specific period of time. Learn what flow variables are and some examples.

forced-liquidation.definition: When a trader's leveraged position is forcibly closed as a result of it not fulfilling the necessary margin requirements.

forex-fx.definition: Forex stands for Foreign Exchange Markets. It's a global market for the trading of fiat currencies.

fork.definition: A fork is a divergence in the blockchain network by creating a split in the blockchain's transaction history. There are two types of forks - soft and hard.

formal-verification.definition: Using mathematically rigorous proofs to ensure certain properties of cryptographic algorithms and blockchain mechanisms

fraud-proof.definition: A fraud proof is a cryptographical evidence that a verifier submits to challenge a transaction's validity. They are widely used for blockchain scalability.

fren.definition: “Fren” is an online slang term used to address someone in a friendly way. It developed in digital communities and is widely used in the crypto community.

full-node.definition: Computer that fully implements the entirety of rules of an underlying blockchain network and validates transactions on a blockchain.

fully-diluted-valuation-fdv.definition: Fully Diluted Valuation (FDV) is a metric that tells us what a crypto project’s market value could be if all its tokens were available for trading now.

fundamental-analysis.definition: Evaluating an asset based on its underlying characteristics and traits as an effort towards arriving at an intrinsic value.

funding-fees.definition: Funding fees are payments made between traders holding long (buy) or short (sell) positions in perpetual futures markets.

fungibility.definition: The property of an asset whose individual units are indistinguishable from each other in terms of value and functionality.

futures-contract.definition: A legal agreement made between a buyer and a seller to trade an asset at a predefined price and date in the future.

gamefi.definition: GameFi is a section of DeFi that merges blockchain technology and gaming, offering play-to-earn incentives through NFTs and cryptocurrencies.

gas.definition: The pricing mechanism employed  on the Ethereum blockchain to calculate the costs of smart contracts operations and transaction fees.

gas-limit.definition: Maximum price a cryptocurrency user is willing to pay as a fee when sending a transaction, or performing a smart contract function.

gdp-deflator.definition: Explore the GDP deflator, an economic tool that measures the inflation in goods and services produced within a country. Learn about its use cases in crypto.

general-public-license.definition: License allowing users to copy and modify software, but requires the works to be distributed under the same license.

genesis-block.definition: The first ever block recorded on its respective blockchain network, also referred to as Block 0 or Block 1.

github.definition: A site/system/folder/repository where a team can share, collaborate, and save their open source or proprietary code.

gm-good-morning.definition: GM stands for "Good Morning," and its use in the crypto community reflects the inclusive and collaborative nature of the space.

golden-cross.definition: A bullish chart pattern where a shorter-term moving average crosses above a longer-term moving average.

golden-ratio.definition: Unlock the secrets of the Golden Ratio in trading! Discover how Fibonacci retracement levels align with this mathematical marvel, influencing market analysis.

goldilocks.definition: Explore the impact of the Goldilocks Principle in economics, its implications for cryptocurrency markets, and how it influences investor sentiment.

gossip-protocol.definition: A particular method of asynchronous peer-to-peer communication between computer nodes of a distributed system.

gross-domestic-product-gdp.definition: Learn what Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is, how it's calculated, its impact on financial and cryptocurrency markets, and why it matters in our economy.

gwei.definition: A small denomination of ether. It is widely used as a measure of gas prices. 1,000,000,000 wei = 1 Giga wei (Gwei)

hackathon.definition: A blockchain hackathon is a competition where participants build sample applications atop a blockchain ecosystem.

hacker.definition: An individual that has an advanced understanding of computer systems and networks, including programmers and cybersecurity experts.

haha-money-printer-go-brrrrr.definition: Haha Money Printer Go Brrrrr is meme created in response to the Federal Reserve's 2020 plan to print money.

halving.definition: Halving is a process that reduces the block reward of a PoW crypto like Bitcoin (BTC) to half. The next halving of Bitcoin is expected around 2024.

hard-cap.definition: The maximum amount of funds a project intends to raise during their Initial Coin Offering (ICO) or alternative fundraising event.

hard-landing.definition: In economic terms, a hard landing refers to a situation where an economy rapidly transitions from growth to slow growth or recession.

hash.definition: The output produced by a hash function after a piece of data is mapped. May also be referred to as hash value, hash code, or digest.

hash-rate.definition: The speed at which a computer or mining hardware is able to calculate new hashes. Usually measured in hashes per second.

hashed-timelock-contract.definition: Refers to a special feature that is used to create smart contracts that are able to modify payment channels.

herd-instinct.definition: Herd instinct describes a phenomenon where traders tend to repeat the actions of the crowd, often without doing their own research.

high-frequency-trading-hft.definition: A type of algorithmic trading that involves the execution of a large number of orders in fractions of a second.

hodl.definition: A typo of 'Hold' originating from bitcointalk that has also been retrofitted to be an acronym for Hold on for Dear Life.

honeypot.definition: A mechanism used in computer security used to detect or counteract unauthorized access of information systems.

iceberg-order.definition: Conditional order to buy or sell a large amount of assets in smaller quantities to conceal the total order quantity.

immutability.definition: The inability to change or be changed. One of the core features behind Bitcoin and blockchain technology.

index.definition: A financial instrument used to track the price value of a given asset or basket of assets

index-funds.definition: Learn about index funds, how they work, their potential benefits and disadvantages, and their potential impact on blockchain and cryptocurrency markets.

initial-coin-offering.definition: A fundraising method in which new projects will sell their cryptocurrency to investors.

initial-dex-offering-ido.definition: An Initial DEX Offering (IDO) is a type of blockchain fundraising method. It’s a public token sale conducted directly on a decentralized exchange (DEX).

initial-exchange-offering.definition: The fundraising will be conducted on a well-known exchange’s fundraising platform, such as Binance Launchpad

initial-public-offering.definition: Refers to the moment a private company starts offering its shares to the public for the first time.

inscription.definition: A piece of data, such as text, images, or code, appended to Bitcoin’s smallest units, satoshis, and stored on the blockchain.

integrated-circuit.definition: A small chip, typically made of silicon, that holds a set of electronic parts such as transistors, resistors or capacitors.

interest-rates.definition: Interest rates can refer either to the cost of borrowing money or the return earned on an investment, usually expressed as a percentage of the principal.

interoperability.definition: A concept of allowing blockchains to be compatible with each other and build upon each other's features and use-cases.

interplanetary-file-system-ipfs.definition: An open-source project building a protocol for distributed content storage and access.

iou.definition: An acronym which stands for “I owe you” and refers to an informal document that acknowledges a debt one party owes to another.

isolated-margin.definition: The margin balance allocated to a position. Traders can manage risk by restricting the amount allocated to each position.

issuance.definition: Generation of a new cryptocurrency which occurs in a variety of different ways, depending on parameters specified by the creators.

keccak.definition: A versatile cryptographic function designed by Guido Bertoni, Joan Daemen, Michaël Peeters, and Gilles Van Assche.

know-your-customer.definition: A standard procedure in the finance industry which allows companies to identify their customers and comply with KYC AML laws

laspeyres-index.definition: Explore the Laspeyres Index, a tool for measuring price changes over time. Understand its uses in traditional markets and applications in cryptocurrencies.

latency.definition: The time between submitting a transaction to a network and the first confirmation of acceptance by the network.

law-of-demand.definition: The law of demand relates to the willingness of consumers to buy a specific amount of goods or services for a particular price.

layer-2.definition: A secondary framework or protocol that is built on top of an existing blockchain system to provide increased scalability.

ledger.definition: A physical book or a digital computer file where monetary and financial transactions are tracked and recorded.

leveraged-tokens.definition: Leveraged tokens are a type of cryptocurrency derivative that allows traders to gain leveraged exposure to a particular cryptocurrency without having to manage the margin requirements.

library.definition: A collection of stable resources, which may include executable files, documentation, message templates, and written code.

lightning-network.definition: A second layer operating on top of a blockchain, enabling increased transaction speed among participating nodes.

limit-order.definition: Learn about limit orders in trading and how they can help you control transaction prices, avoid slippage, and navigate volatile markets effectively.

linux.definition: A popular open-source operating system, created in 1991 by Linus Torvalds. It is used in a wide range of devices around the world.

liquid-staking.definition: Liquid Staking is a popular yield farming method in which users tokenize their staked assets to enhance liquidity and flexibility in DeFi platforms.

liquid-staking-token-lst.definition: Discover Liquid Staking Tokens (LST) in crypto. Learn how to unlock liquidity and flexibility for staked assets. Explore WBETH & DeFi earning opportunities.

liquidity.definition: The ability to sell or buy any given asset without causing significant fluctuations in the market price for that asset.

liquidity-crisis.definition: A liquidity crisis is a financial situation in which an individual, organization, or market faces a shortage of cash, making it difficult to meet immediate financial obligations.

liquidity-provider.definition: Liquidity Providers (LPs) are entities or individuals who supply buy and sell orders to the financial markets to increase market liquidity and ensure a stable and efficient market.

liquidity-ratios.definition: Liquidity ratios are a type of financial metric used to measure a company’s capability to pay short-term obligations.

listing.definition: The addition of an asset to an exchange either as a request from the project team or as a decision made by the exchange.

mainnet.definition: A blockchain protocol which is fully developed and deployed where transactions are being broadcasted, verified, and recorded.

mainnet-swap.definition: When a coin migrates from a third party platform such as Ethereum or other token to a native on-chain token on their mainnet.

maker.definition: When you place an order and it does not trade immediately, your order stays in the order book for someone else to fill/match with it.

malware.definition: Any software program or code that is created to infiltrate and intentionally cause damage to computer systems and networks.

margin-trading.definition: Trading using borrowed funds  - note: this is a high risk strategy and should only be done by experienced investors.

market-capitalization.definition: The total trading value of a given coin - calculated by the product of the supply of the coin by the current price.

market-momentum.definition: The ability of a certain market to maintain a continuous increase or decrease in price within a particular timeframe.

market-order.definition: When a taker picks the best available bid or ask for a cryptocurrency, taking the price and quantity available on the order book.

masternode.definition: Nodes on a network that often require a minimum amount of a given coin staked in order to access staking rewards.

matching-engine.definition: A matching engine is a piece of software designed to process trading orders, ensuring that buyers and sellers are paid correctly in financial markets.

maximum-supply.definition: Refers to the maximum number of coins or tokens that will be ever created for a given cryptocurrency.

mempool.definition: A node’s mechanism for keeping track of unconfirmed transactions that the node has seen (but have not yet been added to a block).

merged-mining.definition: The act of mining two or more cryptocurrencies at the same time, without sacrificing overall mining performance

merkle-tree.definition: A way of organizing and structuring large amounts of data to make it more straightforward to process. A hash-based data structure.

metadata.definition: Data that includes information about other data, such as information about features of a specific transaction.

metaverse.definition: The metaverse is a concept of a persistent, online, 3D virtual environment that many believe will be a key element of future digital experiences.

microtransactions.definition: Explore the world of microtransactions in the context of blockchain and learn how the Lightning Network continues to revolutionize Bitcoin payments.

mining.definition: The verification of transactions on a blockchain network, in which transactions are added as entries into the blockchain ledger.

mining-farm.definition: A collection of many miners, often in a warehouse or large data center devoted to mining cryptocurrencies

mint.definition: Minting adds fresh tokens into the crypto ecosystem, enabling them to be traded or used within its network. Minting is similar to mining, with some key differences.

monetary-policy.definition: Refers to the policies that authorities create and adopt to control the money supply and interest rates of a country.

money-markets.definition: Money markets are places where people and institutions trade short-term financial instruments like T-bills and CDs. Learn more at Binance Academy.

monitoring-tag.definition: A tag used on the Binance platform to classify cryptocurrency projects that are relatively more established when compared to Seed Tag projects.

moon.definition: A colloquial expression used to describe a cryptocurrency or other asset that is experiencing a strong upward market trend.

moving-average-envelopes.definition: Explore moving average envelopes, TA tools composed of two bands set around a central moving average. Learn how they work and what they offer.

moving-average-ribbon.definition: Explore moving average ribbons, combinations of moving averages used for identifying market trends, market momentum, and potential market reversals.

mt-gox.definition: Discover the rise and fall of Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange. Learn about its collapse, security breaches, legal aftermath, and more at Binance Academy.

multisignature.definition: Wallet which requires another party to authorize a transaction before it is broadcasted to the network.

nakamoto-consensus.definition: Learn about the Nakamoto Consensus, an important protocol created by Satoshi Nakamoto that enabled the creation of secure and decentralized blockchain networks.

net-asset-value-nav.definition: NAV is the value of an entity’s assets minus its liabilities. It helps investors understand the price of each share in a mutual fund or ETF.

nft-floor-prices.definition: Floor prices represent the lowest value at which you can purchase an NFT within a collection.

nft-mystery-boxes.definition: Non-fungible token (NFT) mystery boxes are a type of digital collectible that contain a random assortment of NFTs that are unknown the buyer until they open the box.

ngmi.definition: NGMI is an acronym for "Not Gonna Make It,” used to convey a sense of pessimism in achieving success or overcoming a challenge.

node.definition: A participant on a blockchain network that communicates with other participants to ensure the security and integrity of the system.

non-fungible-token-nft.definition: A type of cryptographic token that represents a unique digital or real-world asset and isn't interchangeable.

nonce.definition: A single-use arbitrary string or number generated for verification purposes to prevent replaying past transactions.

oco-order.definition: An OCO (One Cancels the Other) order allows you to place two orders at the same time. It combines a limit order with a stop-limit order but only one of them can be executed.

off-chain.definition: Discover how off-chain transactions in crypto enhance scalability and speed. Explore their use in Layer 2 solutions, reducing transaction costs.

offline-signing-orchestrator-oso.definition: Offline Signing Orchestrator (OSO) is a technology developed by IBM to enhance the security of crypto and digital assets when they are stored in cold storage.

offshore-account.definition: An account that is registered in a jurisdiction that is different to the jurisdiction of the holder's citizenship.

on-chain.definition: On-chain refers to transactions and activities directly recorded on the blockchain, ensuring data transparency, security, and immutability.

opbnb.definition: opBNB acts as an important layer-2 scaling solution, which strategically offloads transaction processing and resource usage from the BNB Smart Chain.

open-source-software-oss.definition: Software released under a license that gives anyone the ability and right to use, update, and distribute it freely.

opportunity-cost.definition: Discover the role of opportunity cost in economics and trading, and how it can help you make better decisions. Learn how to calculate the opportunity cost.

oracle.definition: A data source or feed from a third party used for determining outcomes for smart contracts.

orc-20-tokens.definition: ORC-20 tokens run on the Bitcoin blockchain and are represented as JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) files inscribed onto satoshis with an Ordinal serial number, similar to BRC-20 tokens.

order-book.definition: An electronic list of outstanding buy and sell orders for a specific asset on an exchange or marketplace.

ordinals.definition: Ordinals are NFT-like entities that can be minted directly on the Bitcoin blockchain.

orphan-block.definition: A block whose parent block is unknown, formed in older versions of Bitcoin Core, where ancestry data wasn't required.

pancakeswap.definition: PancakeSwap is a decentralized exchange (DEX) that uses an AMM model. It's available in multiple blockchain networks with various DeFi products and services.

paper-wallet.definition: A piece of paper on which the public and private keys of a cryptocurrency address are physically printed out.

parallelization.definition: Parallelization is an approach to transaction processing that structures the network to validate multiple transactions simultaneously.

passive-management.definition: An investing strategy that doesn’t rely on active market exposure but rather tracks an existing economic index.

peer-to-peer.definition: When two or more computers are connected and share workload or resources without relying on a centralized server.

pegged-currency.definition: A pegged currency is a type of currency whose value is closely tied to the value of another currency, commodity, or basket of currencies.

permissionless-blockchain.definition: Permissionless blockchains are open networks that allow anyone to participate in the consensus process without the need to obtain approval, permission, or authorization.

phishing.definition: A malicious attack where a bad actor will attempt to obtain the credentials of a user in order to gain unauthorised access into their account.

plasma.definition: An Ethereum off-chain scaling solution which may allow Etherum to greatly increase the transactions per second capablities.

polkadot-crowdloan.definition: A crowdsourcing system that allows participants to support specific projects by staking DOT.

ponzi-scheme.definition: A scam in which new investors' funds are used to pay returns promised to previous investors. Do not invest in these.

premining.definition: Learn about premining in blockchain and cryptocurrencies, its purpose, potential benefits, disadvantages, criticisms, and impact on market performance.

price-action.definition: The price movements of a financial asset over time. Plotted on a chart, it can be used by traders to identify trade setups.

prisoners-dilemma.definition: An example that shows why two individuals might not cooperate, even if it may appear to be in their best interest.

private-key.definition: In the context of cryptocurrency, a private key is a number that allows users to sign transactions and to generate receiving addresses.

private-sale.definition: An early stage investment round for strategic investors with a considerable amount of investible funds.

progressive-web-application.definition: An application that is created through the use of modern web technologies and follows basic web standards.

proof-of-attendance-protocol-poap.definition: A protocol that creates digital badges or collectibles to celebrate and record the attendance of an event. POAPs are minted as ERC-721 tokens on the Ethereum blockchain.

proof-of-reserves-por.definition: Proof of Reserves (PoR) is a verification proving an exchange maintains funds to cover users' assets.

proof-of-stake.definition: A consensus mechanism that reward block validators according to the amount of coins they have at stake.

proof-of-staked-authority-posa.definition: Proof of Staked Authority merges Proof of Stake and Proof of Authority, enhancing blockchain security through its equal staking and balanced validation system

proof-of-work.definition: Proof of Work is a crypto consensus mechanism where miners use special equipment to solve cryptographic puzzles to validate transactions and create new blocks.

proposer-builder-separation-pbs.definition: Proposer-builder separation (PBS) is an Ethereum concept aiming to improve scalability by dividing the responsibilities of block building into block proposers and block builders.

proto-danksharding.definition: Proto-danksharding serves as a temporary scalability solution before the implementation of danksharding, which marks the final phase of Ethereum 2.0 (Serenity).

pseudorandom.definition: The property of a definite function that can produce an outcome that passes statistical tests of randomness.

public-key.definition: A public key is one-half of a key pair used to encrypt messages or verify digital signatures. In the crypto space, it essentially works as your wallet address.

pump-and-dump.definition: Pump-and-dumps are a deceptive practice used in crypto, where the price of a digital asset is artificially inflated and dumped, causing a sharp decline in the token value.

quantitative-easing-qe.definition: Learn about Quantitative Easing (QE), a tool that central banks use to boost economies. Understand its impacts on financial and cryptocurrency markets.

quantitative-tightening-qt.definition: Learn about quantitative tightening and its impact on financial and crypto markets. Understand how central banks' policies affect asset prices and sentiment.

quantum-computing.definition: Using particles that can be in superposition. These particles represent qubits and can take the value of 1, 0 or both.

race-attack.definition: When two transactions are created with the same funds at the same time, with the intention of spending those funds twice.

ransomware.definition: A type of malware which takes over your computer and threatens to destroy or reveal files unless a ransom is paid.

real-world-assets-rwas.definition: Real World Assets refer to tangible, physical assets with intrinsic value—like real estate, commodities, or art—that are tokenized for use on the blockchain.

recession.definition: Understanding recessions and how they can affect cryptocurrency markets: Explore the complexities and uncertainties when economic downturns meet digital assets.

recursive-inscription.definition: Recursive inscription involves embedding information within itself, creating a loop of reference. Learn how it works in the Bitcoin and cryptocurrency space.

rekt.definition: A slang term used to define someone or something that has been destroyed or experienced catastrophic failure and a synonym for liquidated

relative-strength-index.definition: A technical indicator that measures market momentum & used to identify overbought and oversold conditions.

resistance.definition: A term in Technical Analysis (TA). When a price that is increasing finds resistance. Usually compared with previous highs.

return-on-investment.definition: A measure used in order to assess the efficiency of an investment. The ratio between net profit and net cost.

revenge-trading.definition: Explore the concept of revenge trading, how it works, and what its dangers are. Learn how it can impact traders financially and emotionally.

risk-premium.definition: Risk premium in finance is the return investors expect or demand for higher risk, essential for informed investment decisions. Learn more at Binance Academy.

roadmap.definition: A business planning technique which lays out the short and long term goals of a company within a flexible estimated timeline.

routing-attack.definition: Attack on the Internet Service Provider level to affect uptime or participation in a web-enabled system, such as a blockchain.

rug-pull.definition: A rug pull in the crypto industry is when a development team suddenly abandons a project and sells or removes all its liquidity.

sahm-rule.definition: The Sahm Rule detects recessions by monitoring unemployment rates. If the 3-month average rises by 0.5% from the lowest in the past year, a recession is likely.

sandwich-trading.definition: Sandwich trading, also known as sandwich attacks or sandwiching, is a trading strategy or manipulation technique in the cryptocurrency markets.

satoshi.definition: The smallest unit of a bitcoin, as defined by the Bitcoin protocol. It equals one-hundred-millionth of a bitcoin or 0.00000001 BTC.

satoshi-nakamoto.definition: Satoshi Nakamoto was the pseudonym of the creator or creators of the bitcoin protocol and whitepaper.

secure-asset-fund-for-users.definition: Secure Asset Fund for Users is an emergency insurance fund created by Binance in 2018.

securities-and-exchange-commission.definition: An independent governmental agency responsible for regulating securities markets.

security-audit.definition: A systematic analysis to evaluate how safe a system, smart contract, or blockchain is against attacks or technical failures.

security-token-offering-sto.definition: Unravel Security Token Offering (STO), a method of raising capital by issuing security tokens. Explore some of the benefits they offer to investors.

seed-phrase.definition: A seed phrase or menmonic seed is a collection of words that can be used to access your cryptocurrency wallet.

seed-tag.definition: A tag used to classify cryptocurrencies that are usually in their initial stages of development and may not yet have a working product or established user base.

segregated-witness.definition: Segregated Witness, often abbreviated to SegWit, is an update to the Bitcoin protocol designed to address the network’s scalability and security issues.

selfish-mining.definition: The strategic withholding and releasing of blocks by a miner in order to gain a competitive advantage over the network.

sell-wall.definition: A very large limit sell order or a cumulation of sell orders at the same price level on an order book for an asset.

sentiment.definition: The overall attitude of a community in regards to a cryptocurrency or within investors towards a certain financial market.

sharding.definition: Sharding is a method of splitting blockchains ( or other types of databases) into smaller, partitioned blockchains that manage specific data segments.

sharpe-ratio.definition: A ratio created in 1966 that investors and economists use to assess the potential return of investment (ROI).

sidechains.definition: Sidechains are independent blockchains linked to a parent blockchain, designed to enhance scalability and facilitate digital asset transfers between networks.

simple-moving-average-sma.definition: Explore simple moving averages (SMAs), fundamental technical analysis tools that traders use to identify market trends and potential buy or sell signals.

slashing.definition: Slashing is a mechanism to punish malicious or negligent behavior in blockchains that rely on staking and use the Proof of Stake (PoS) consensus mechanism.

slippage.definition: Slippage occurs when a trade settles at a different price than originally requested or expected, usually in low-liquidity markets and when using market orders.

smart-contract.definition: Smart contracts are self-executing contracts that exist on certain blockchain networks. Their conditions and terms are written directly into lines of code.

smart-contract-wallet.definition: Smart contract wallets are crypto wallets that leverage programmable smart contracts to introduce advanced functionalities and enhanced security features.

snapshot.definition: The ability to record the state of a blockchain ledger, storage device, or computer system at a specific point in time.

social-recovery-wallet.definition: Social recovery wallets are crypto wallets allowing crypto recovery. They utilize trusted contacts so users can regain access in case of lost keys or forgotten passwords.

social-trading.definition: Social trading is a strategy that enables individuals to mimic the trading behavior of expert investors and market professionals, often in real time.

socialfi.definition: SocialFi, short for Social Finance, represents a convergence of decentralized finance (DeFi) principles with the dynamics of social media.

soft-landing.definition: Soft landing refers to a situation in which the economy slows down gradually after a period of rapid growth while simultaneously avoiding a recession.

solidity.definition: Solidity is a programming language created in 2014 that was specifically designed to write and implement smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain.

source-code.definition: Computer code, which is responsible for defining how software will function based on a list of instructions and statements.

spl.definition: SPL stands for Solana Program Library (SPL). It is a set of rules and protocols governing how tokens behave and interact on the Solana network.

src-20-tokens.definition: SRC-20 is a token standard that expands the utility of the Bitcoin blockchain by leveraging Bitcoin Stamps to issue fungible tokens on the Bitcoin network.

stablecoin.definition: A type of cryptocurrency that is designed to maintain a stable value, rather than experiencing significant price changes.

stagflation.definition: Stagflation is an economic challenge that includes slow economic growth, higher scarcity of job offerings, and inflation (rising prices of goods and services).

staking-pool.definition: A pool where stakeholders combine their staking power to increase their chance of successfully validating a new block.

state-channel.definition: A two-way communication channel between two users or nodes on a network, or between a user and a service.

steth.definition: Discover stETH, a tokenized representation of Ethereum staking rewards. Learn how it enhances accessibility and liquidity in cryptocurrency investments.

stock-variable.definition: Explore stock variables, quantities of economic resources measured at a particular point in time. Learn some examples of stock variables in crypto.

store-of-value.definition: A commodity, asset or currency that can be saved, retrieved and exchanged at a future date, without suffering depreciation.

supercomputer.definition: A computer or virtual machine that operates at the highest level of currently possible computing power.

supply-chain.definition: A network of people and businesses involved in creating and distributing a particular product or serving a particular customer.

support.definition: A term in Technical Analysis (TA). When a price that is decreasing finds 'support'. Usually compared with lows.

sybil-attack.definition: Learn about Sybil attacks, a cyber threat where fake identities can manipulate networks, potentially impacting financial and cryptocurrency markets.

taker.definition: The 'taker' is someone who decides to place an order that is instantly matched with an existing order on the order book.

tank.definition: A term adopted from the traditional financial markets and describes a strong negative financial performance of a particular asset

testnet.definition: Testnets are replicas of the mainnet, offering risk-free, secure environments for exploring and testing blockchain features.

ticker.definition: The trading 'symbol' or shortened name (typically in capital letters) that refer to a coin on a trading platform. For example: BNB

ticker-symbol.definition: A ticker symbol is a shorthand code that represents a stock, bond, cryptocurrency, or other traded asset. Learn more at Binance Academy.

token.definition: Tokens (not to be confused with coins) are digital units issued on a blockchain. They can hold value or be redeemed for assets.

token-generation-event-tge.definition: Token generation event (TGE): a crowdfunding method for blockchain projects. Learn what TGEs are, their pros and cons, and how they differ from ICOs.

token-lockup.definition: Token lockup or vesting period refers to the time span in which tokens or coins are not allowed to be transferred or traded.

token-merge.definition: A token merge happens when two or more crypto tokens are combined into a single token. Learn about token merge and its potential impact on crypto prices.

token-sale.definition: The issuance of tokens in exchange for another cryptocurrency. Also referred to as an Initial Coin Offering.

token-standards.definition: Learn about ERC-20, ERC-721, BEP-20, and TRC-20 token standards in blockchain networks. Understand their role in cryptocurrency transactions and decentralized applications.

tokenization.definition: Tokenization refers to the process of converting real-world assets, such as real estate, art, or financial instruments, into digital tokens on a blockchain.

tokenomics.definition: The word “tokenomics” combines two words, ‘token’ and ‘economics.’ It allows us to see how a token functions, along with various factors that may affect its value

total-supply.definition: Refers to the number of coins or tokens that currently exists and are either in circulation or locked somehow.

total-value-locked-tvl.definition: Total Value Locked (TVL) is a widely used metric in the cryptocurrency industry that measures the total value of assets locked in a decentralized finance (DeFi) protocol.

tradfi.definition: TradFi (traditional finance) is the established financial system most people interact with in their daily lives.

transaction-id.definition: A transaction ID (TXID) is a unique string of characters that labels each transaction on the blockchain.

transactions-per-second-tps.definition: The number of transactions that a blockchain network is capable of processing each second.

treasury-bills-t-bills.definition: T-bills are low-risk government securities that can impact interest rates and market sentiment. Learn what T-bills are and how they work at Binance Academy.

trueusd-tusd.definition: TrueUSD is a stablecoin pegged to the U.S. dollar. It is integrated with multiple blockchain networks and is among the fastest-growing stablecoins.

trustless.definition: No single entity has authority over the system and consensus is achieved between participants who do not have to trust each other.

turing-complete.definition: A machine that, given enough time and memory along with the necessary instructions, can solve any computational problem.

understanding-cz-s-number-4.definition: The number 4 represents one of CZ’s New Years resolutions to ignore FUD, fake news and  attacks on Binance.

unit-of-account.definition: One of the primary properties of money. Allowing measurement and comparison of the value of different things.

unspent-transaction-output-utxo.definition: An output created in a transaction, which must be referenced in a future transaction to spend funds.

user-interface.definition: The interface where interactions between humans and machines occur. It establishes how a user can interact with a machine.

utility-token.definition: A digital token issued through a blockchain network, often via an initial coin offering (ICO), initial exchange offering (IEO) or token generation event (TGE).

verification-code.definition: Code sent to a second device to ensure the identity of someone logging in to an account. Used for Two-Factor Authentication

virtual-machine.definition: An emulated computer system, or a distributed system that is designed to replicate the features of a computer's architecture.

vladimir-club.definition: A term used to describe someone who has acquired 1% of 1% (0.01%) of the maximum supply of a cryptocurrency.

volatility.definition: How quickly and how much the price of an asset changes. Calculated in terms of standard deviations in the annual return of an asset

volume.definition: A measurement of the number of individual units of an asset that changed hands in a market during a given time.

wagmi.definition: WAGMI is an acronym for "We’re All Gonna Make It" that encourages an optimistic attitude, particularly within the crypto community.

wallet.definition: Used to send and receive cryptocurrencies. Different types include software wallets, hardware wallets, and paper wallets.

wash-trading.definition: Wash trading is an unethical and deceptive practice involving the simultaneous buying and selling of a certain asset to create false market activity.

weak-hands.definition: A term referring to traders or investors who lack the confidence to hold their assets or to follow their trading plans.

weak-subjectivity.definition: Relates to the need for certain nodes to rely on other nodes when determining the current state of a PoS blockchain.

web-1.definition: The initial iteration of the web, when data was primarily read-only pages connected with hyperlinks. Also known as 'read-only' web.

wei.definition: The smallest possible denomination of ether (ETH), the currency used on the Ethereum network. Often used when referring to gas prices.

weighted-moving-average-wma.definition: Discover weighted moving averages (WMAs), fundamental technical analysis tools that smooth out price data with greater sensitivity to recent price changes.

whale.definition: An individual or organization that holds a large amount of Bitcoins or other cryptocurrency, allowing them to impact the markets.

whiskers.definition: Lines extending from a colored bar in a candlestick chart that indicate the low-high range of a trading pair within a time frame.

whitelist.definition: A list of allowed or trusted individuals, computer programs, or cryptocurrency addresses in relation to a service or event.

wick.definition: Line found on a candlestick chart used to indicate where the price of an asset is fluctuating in regards to its opening and closing price

win-rate.definition: In financial markets, win rate (or win ratio) is a metric that indicates how profitable a trader might be.

wrapped-ether.definition: ERC-20 token representing Ether at a 1:1 ratio. It allows users to trade ETH to ERC-20 tokens on decentralized platforms.

wyckoff.definition: The Wyckoff method, created by Richard Wyckoff in the 1930s, is an approach to trading and investing that caused a lasting impact on modern technical analysis.

yield-farming.definition: Yield farming is a high-risk practice in DeFi where investors lock up assets to provide liquidity, lend or stake in return for rewards or interest.

zero-knowledge-proofs.definition: Verify transactions are valid without revealing any information about the transactions, providing privacy.

zk-rollup.definition: Zk-rollup is a layer-2 scaling solution designed to increase the transaction throughput of blockchain networks without compromising on security.

zk-snarks.definition: “Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge” - an approach to zero-knowledge proofs.

zk-starks.definition: zk-STARKs allow one party (the prover) to communicate validated data or execute computations with a third party without the data or analysis being revealed to the counterparty (the verifier).
